--- CLINICAL HISTORY ---
Pineoblastomas are uncommon pineal tumors, which demonstrate rapid growing and poor prognosis. We report the case of a 14-year-old girl who presented  a pineoblastoma with unusual venticular extension.

--- IMAGING FINDINGS ---
A 14-year-old girl presented with a 6-week history of severe headache. Neurological examination showed bilateral papilledema. Computed tomography revealed a pineal region mass without hydrocephalus. Brain MR imaging was performed 2 months later in a 1.5T scanner with standard technique (T1-weightedimages before and after intravenous contrast administration). It showed a pineal region tumor continuously invading through the tectum into the cerebral aqueduct with the preservation of the adjacent structures. The tumor appeared an iso to hypointense mass on T1-weighted images, a heterogeneous iso to hyperintense mass on T2-weighted images, and a heterogeneously enhanced mass after administration of contrast medium. Histological examination after endoscopic biopsy of the pineal region, confirmed that the tumor was a pineoblastoma. There was evidence of dissemination in the chiasmatic region, but no other localisation in the rest of the central nervous system or any systemic metastatic lesions. Radiotherapy was given to the whole brain and the spinal cord, and magnetic resonance imaging showed  remission of the tumor.

--- DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSIS ---
Pineoblastoma

--- FINAL DIAGNOSIS ---
Pineoblastoma

A 43 years old male patient was referred to our hospital due to acute abdominal pain.  A medical history of appendectomy but no concomitant diseases were known. Physical examination revealed pressure pain of the whole abdomen. No other significant findings were noted. Laboratory data showed high C- reactive protein value of 314 mg/l. This study showed a fatty cystic mass with circular contrast enhancement and 5.3 cm x 6.3 cm in size.
